Technical Blog

JavaScript Objects vs Ruby Hashes

Friday, September 11, 2015

If you were to look at a JavaScript Object next to a Ruby Hash, you would think that they are very similiar. In fact, in many respects, you would be correct. A JavaScript Object stores its information in properties, which are set up like:

var Name = {
          property: information
        }

Notice how the property and information are set up and how it is all stored between the curly brackets? Now let's look at a Ruby Hash:

Hash = {key: value}

They seem the same, right? In the Ruby Hash, the key takes the role of the property, and the value takes the role of the information from the JavaScript Object.

One of the main differences between a JavaScript Object and a Ruby is how we retrieve the information from them. In a JavaScript Object, we use Dot Notation: "Name.property" will give us "information". In Ruby, we use the notation: "Hash[:key]" to get the result "value". Both function in very much the same way, they are just written a little differently. This is not to say that the two are interchangeable. JavaScript and Ruby are not the same language, and each has its own strengths, weaknesses and uses.
